What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, stereotypes by themselves are not always harmful, as they are simply a shortcut that people make when they do not have enough information about an individual.  However, even though they are not intended to be harmful, they often can be, especially to the person who is being judged.

I cringe when I see a character that is a stereotype because it makes me feel like the author is lazy.

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, stereotypes by themselves are not always harmful, as they are simply a shortcut that people make when they do not have enough information about an individual.  However, even though they are not intended to be harmful, they often can be, especially to the person who is being judged.  

I cringe when I see a character that is a stereotype because it makes me feel like the author is lazy, but I also feel that this use of stereotyping might end up being harmful to the group that the author is writing about.  For example, if an author writes about black youths who end up committing crimes, this would further strengthen society's expectations that young black males are violent, and this will lead others not to trust them.  Clearly, this is not right, because crime comes from poverty, not from race.

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, stereotypes by themselves are not always harmful, as they are simply a shortcut that people make when they do not have enough information about an individual.  However, even though they are not intended to be harmful, they often can be, especially to the person who is being judged.  

I cringe when I see a character that is a stereotype because it makes me feel like the author is lazy, but I also feel that this use of stereotyping might end up being harmful to the group that the author is writing about.  For example, if an author writes about black youths who end up committing crimes, this would further strengthen society's expectations that young black males are violent, and this will lead others not to trust them.  Clearly, this is not right, because crime comes from poverty, not from race.  

I was fortunate in life to have been born a white male, which gives me definite advantages.  However, if I was a member of a minority group, I would prefer not to watch or read something that is offensive to me, because I would feel like the author is being disrespectful to me.  I would also feel that I was rewarding this conduct on the part of authors and screenwriters, which would further encourage it.  

As a member of the majority, though, I do still cringe when I see minority groups portrayed in an insensitive, stereotypical fashion on TV, in movies, and to a lesser extent in books.  This not only harms the group as a whole, but it also affects individual actors.  When there are no roles available for minority actors except for those that perpetuate stereotypes, these actors are either left without opportunities, or they have to betray their morals in order to keep working.  

If people were more apt to reject stereotypes, these difficult decisions would not have to be made.

What Do You Think About Stereotypes?

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, stereotypes by themselves are not always harmful, as they are simply a shortcut that people make when they do not have enough information about an individual.  However, even though they are not intended to be harmful, they often can be, especially to the person who is being judged.  

I cringe when I see a character that is a stereotype because it makes me feel like the author is lazy, but I also feel that this use of stereotyping might end up being harmful to the group that the author is writing about.  For example, if an author writes about black youths who end up committing crimes, this would further strengthen society's expectations that young black males are violent, and this will lead others not to trust them.  Clearly, this is not right, because crime comes from poverty, not from race.  

I was fortunate in life to have been born a white male, which gives me definite advantages.  However, if I was a member of a minority group, I would prefer not to watch or read something that is offensive to me, because I would feel like the author is being disrespectful to me.  I would also feel that I was rewarding this conduct on the part of authors and screenwriters, which would further encourage it.  

As a member of the majority, though, I do still cringe when I see minority groups portrayed in an insensitive, stereotypical fashion on TV, in movies, and to a lesser extent in books.  This not only harms the group as a whole, but it also affects individual actors.  When there are no roles available for minority actors except for those that perpetuate stereotypes, these actors are either left without opportunities, or they have to betray their morals in order to keep working.  

If people were more apt to reject stereotypes, these difficult decisions would not have to be made.  

Stereotypes do not always have to be negative, however.  Someone might assume that a young Asian person is smart, especially at math, or that someone who wears glasses is a good student.  They might assume that Native Americans are noble in spirit, or that elderly African Americans are devoted to family values.  I generally do not have a negative reaction to these stereotypes, because I do not see any acute harm that comes from them, but they are still lazy.  One should not assume that the circumstances of one's birth have any impact on their character or their abilities.

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, stereotypes by themselves are not always harmful, as they are simply a shortcut that people make when they do not have enough information about an individual.  However, even though they are not intended to be harmful, they often can be, especially to the person who is being judged.  

I cringe when I see a character that is a stereotype because it makes me feel like the author is lazy, but I also feel that this use of stereotyping might end up being harmful to the group that the author is writing about.  For example, if an author writes about black youths who end up committing crimes, this would further strengthen society's expectations that young black males are violent, and this will lead others not to trust them.  Clearly, this is not right, because crime comes from poverty, not from race.  

I was fortunate in life to have been born a white male, which gives me definite advantages.  However, if I was a member of a minority group, I would prefer not to watch or read something that is offensive to me, because I would feel like the author is being disrespectful to me.  I would also feel that I was rewarding this conduct on the part of authors and screenwriters, which would further encourage it.  

As a member of the majority, though, I do still cringe when I see minority groups portrayed in an insensitive, stereotypical fashion on TV, in movies, and to a lesser extent in books.  This not only harms the group as a whole, but it also affects individual actors.  When there are no roles available for minority actors except for those that perpetuate stereotypes, these actors are either left without opportunities, or they have to betray their morals in order to keep working.  

If people were more apt to reject stereotypes, these difficult decisions would not have to be made.  

Stereotypes do not always have to be negative, however.  Someone might assume that a young Asian person is smart, especially at math, or that someone who wears glasses is a good student.  They might assume that Native Americans are noble in spirit, or that elderly African Americans are devoted to family values.  I generally do not have a negative reaction to these stereotypes, because I do not see any acute harm that comes from them, but they are still lazy.  One should not assume that the circumstances of one's birth have any impact on their character or their abilities.  After all, if you automatically assume that an Asian student is going to be the best in the class, aren't you also assuming that the other students are naturally inferior, because of their race?

So, in summary, I do not think that it is wrong to have a stereotype.  This is something that happens automatically within our brains, and we can't really stop these thoughts from popping up.  But I think that it is wrong to judge someone based on a stereotype that either comes from within, or that we have picked up from society at large.  

Not only do stereotypes lead to negative judgments against others, which sometimes have real-world consequences, but they also prevent people from enjoying the kinds of equal opportunities that all of us deserve.

As a member of the majority, though, I do still cringe when I see minority groups portrayed in an insensitive, stereotypical fashion on TV, in movies, and to a lesser extent in books.
